author: greystroke
content: Can we discuss uncapping the deposit/withdrawal queues in Glamsterdam back to the old system where it scaled with the total amount of ETH staked? 43 days to withdraw is just bad mechanics & UX plus with consolidations now in full swing, the arbitrary 256 ETH limits no longer seem necessary and sre actually counterproductive.  At the very least, we should lift the  churn cap on the withdrawal queue.

author: tersec
content: This trades off against the weak subjectivity period, no?

author: greystroke
content: The reason for the 256 ETH hard cap was the validator set was growing too fast. This is no longer the case. Even if that is a concern (I dont think it is personally), no reason to keep withdrawal capped at 256 ETH/epoch still.

author: fradamt
content: the cap on withdrawals isn't related to the validator set growing too fast, it's about weak subjectivity and the hit to that with the introduction to consolidations

author: fradamt
content: The choices are being fine with the weak subjectivity loss, or reducing the churn allocated to consolidations

author: greystroke
content: Considering the consolidations operation barely getting any use (most are just withdrawing and redeposit as 0x02 validators), is this even a worthwhile tradeoff?

author: fradamt
content: It would be helpful to understand what *all* staking pools think about this, since so little of the stake has been consolidated at this point. If it is indeed the case that this is what everyone is planning to do, it could make sense to reduce the consolidation churn in favor of exit churn

author: greystroke
content: Considering the earliest this change could happen is Glamsterdam and that about at least a year away but we are scoping it out now, definitely something to be actively considered.
